title: Git for R
text:
About this book
Iâ€™m finding Iâ€™m not happy with existing resources on using Git with R, so I want to make a very opinionated guide specifically for my students.

title: 2Â  Introduction
text:
3 Introduction to Version control
What is version control?
Version control is a system that helps you track and manage changes to files over time. It lets you save different versions of your work, go back to earlier versions if you make a mistake, and work with other people without overwriting each otherâ€™s changes.
Imagine youâ€™re writing a paper. Every time you make a big edit, you save a new copy: paper_v1.docx, paper_v2.docx, paper_final.docx, etc.
Version control keeps track of these versions for you. Have you ever used the versions feature in Google docs when working on an article draft? Then youâ€™ve interacted with version control.
What is Git?
To keep track of versions of coding projects, programmers use a version control tool called Git. It runs on your computer and helps you:
You can think of Git like a very smart â€œsave gameâ€ system for your projects. Unlike in Google docs, our versions arenâ€™t automatically saved for us. We have to tell our computers when and how to save a new version.
How GitHub fits into this:
GitHub is a website that hosts Git repositories (your project + its history) online.
It lets you:
If Git is your notebook where you track all your work, GitHub is like an online library where you can store a copy of your notebook â€” and invite others to read it or even help you write it.
In short:

title: 2Â  Introduction
text:
3.1 Prerequisites:
Before we move on to working with Git and Github, we need to make sure you have what you need to successfully complete the exercises in this guide. The guide assumes you already have the following installed on your computer:

R
RStudio
Quarto

If you are missing any these, please go to the links listed and make sure to install before moving on to the next chapter!

title: 3Â  Installation and setup
text:
3.1 Step 1: Install the Tools
Before we can get started, weâ€™ll need to make sure that our computers (often referred to as our local machines) are set up correctly. Letâ€™s do that by completing the following steps:

title: 3Â  Installation and setup
text:
Install Git

Go to: https://git-scm.com/downloads
Download and install Git
Default install settings are fine

Sign up for a Github account:

Go to: https://github.com
Click Sign up
Choose a username and email youâ€™ll remember (youâ€™ll use this in Git config)

title: 3Â  Installation and setup
section: 3.2 Step 2: Set Up Git in the Terminal
text:
3.2 Step 2: Set Up Git in the Terminal
After installing Git, youâ€™ll need to configure it with your name and email. Open the terminal (you can find this in RStudio under the â€œTerminalâ€ tab) and run the following commands:
First, weâ€™ll set up our username.
About Git usernames:
Usernames are what git uses to associate your work with your identity. For now, just know that the name you set here will be visible in any work you send to Github. You do not have to use your real name.
Setting your Git username
Run the following command from your Terminal, replacing â€œYour Nameâ€ with the username youâ€™d like to use (including the quotation marks):
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
Check to see if you successfully set your name by running:
git config user.name
You should see a Terminal response message with the username you entered. If you didnâ€™t get the response expected, then try again. Remember, be careful about punctuation.
Once you have your username set properly, weâ€™ll set your email.






Caution



Remember, the username you set here will be visible (read: public) in any future commits you push to GitHub. If you choose to use a nickname or alias instead of your real name, keep it professional enough that you wouldnâ€™t mind a future employer or colleague seeing it if you needed to share your work.


Setting your git email
The email you enter needs to match the one you used to setup your Github account.
Set your user email by running the following command, replacing â€œyour.email@example.comâ€ with your Github email:
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"






Important



Your git email should be the same as the one you use on GitHub so your commits will be linked correctly

title: 3Â  Installation and setup
text:
3.3 Exercise 1: Confirm Your Git Setup
Open RStudioâ€™s terminal (bottom-left pane)
Type and execute the following command:
git --version
You should see something like:
git version 2.42.0
Then check your Git config:
bash git config --list
Look for your name and email in the list. If you see them, youâ€™re all set!

3.3.1 âœ… If You See Your Name + Email, Youâ€™re Ready!
If not, go back and run:
git config --global user.name "Your Name" git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

title: 3Â  Installation and setup
section: 3.4 ğŸ§  What Do These Flags Mean?
text:
3.4 ğŸ§  What Do These Flags Mean?
Letâ€™s break down some of the options youâ€™ve used:

--global: This means â€œapply this setting for all projects on my computer.â€
You usually only need to set your name and email globally once.
--list: This tells Git to â€œshow me my current configuration.â€


3.4.1 âœ… Youâ€™re Set!
Now that Git is configured, youâ€™re ready to create your first project. In the next chapter, weâ€™ll walk you through creating a new Quarto project with Git tracking from the start â€” using the terminal.

title: 3Â  Making a repository
text:
3.1 Step 1: Create a new RStudio Project
Open RStudio and make a new Quarto project by going to:
In the project wizard, do the following:
Youâ€™ll now have a project with a .qmd file (Quarto), and RStudio will open into a new window for this project.

title: 3Â  Making a repository
text:
File â†’ New Project â†’ New Directory â†’ Quarto Project


Select New directory in Create Project.
Select Quarto project as the Project Type.
Give your directory a descriptive name like my-first-git-project.
Check the Create project as a subdirectory of to make sure youâ€™re creating your project in the directory where you keep your class or coding projects (ideally a projects folder inside your home directory).
Finallay, click Create Project.




3.1.1 Exercise 1: Run a Quarto File
Before we get into Git, letâ€™s test Quarto by creating a new file.

Click the new file icon at the top left of R Studio and click â€œQuarto documentâ€¦â€ (or go to File > New File > Quarto documentâ€¦)
Add a title like â€œIntro to Gitâ€, and click Create
Save the file and name it something like 01-index.qmd when prompted
Click Render in the top bar

You should see an HTML preview with sample content. Great! Youâ€™re ready to start version-controlling this project.

title: 3Â  Making a repository
section: 3.2 Step 2: Initialize Git for the Project
text:
3.2 Step 2: Initialize Git for the Project
If we want Git to start watching our files and keeping track of our changes, we have to make sure Git is connected to our project. To do this, we need initialize git inside of our Quarto project.
To initialize Git in your Quarto project, Click the Terminal tab in RStudio (usually lower-left)
Inside Terminal, type the following command and run it (by hitting enter):
git init
In basic terms, this tells Git â€œI want you to start tracking this folder.â€
If it works, youâ€™ll see Terminal respond with something like:
Initialized empty Git repository in /Users/yourname/my-quarto-project/.git/

title: 3Â  Making a repository
section: 3.3 ğŸ—‚ï¸ Step 3: Tell Git What Files to Track
text:
3.3 ğŸ—‚ï¸ Step 3: Tell Git What Files to Track
Now that weâ€™ve let Git know that we want it to start watching our project, weâ€™ll also need to tell git what files we would like it to keep track of.
First, letâ€™s ask Git what it â€œseesâ€ in our project folder by running:
git status
Terminal will return something like the following as a response:
On branch main

No commits yet

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        .Rproj.user/
        .quarto/
        _quarto.yml
        my-first-git-project.Rproj
        my-first-git-project.html
        my-first-git-project.qmd
        my-first-git-project_files/

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
Now, letâ€™s breakdown what this all means:

On branch main: Youâ€™re working on the main branch â€” the default starting line of development.
No commits yet: This means Git is ready, but you havenâ€™t saved any versions yet.
Untracked Files: These are files Git sees in your folder, but itâ€™s not saving changes to them yet. Theyâ€™re marked in red in the terminal and the RStudio Git tab.

In the next step, weâ€™ll learn how to tell Git what files weâ€™d like it to track and which files to ignore.

title: 4Â  Creating your first commit
text:
4.1 Ignoring files
In our last chapter, we ran the git status command to tell us what Git sees within our project.
Letâ€™s take another look at those files now by re-running:
Under untracked files youâ€™ll see a list like:
Notice that .html file in the list. This .html file is the rendered output from Quarto, which changes every time you click â€œRender.â€ We generally do not save these kinds of rendered files in our repositories since itâ€™s like saving every draft printout of a paper â€” not helpful.

title: 4Â  Creating your first commit
text:
git status

        .Rproj.user/
        .quarto/
        _quarto.yml
        my-first-git-project.Rproj
        my-first-git-project.html
        my-first-git-project.qmd
        my-first-git-project_files/

title: 4Â  Creating your first commit
text:
4.2 ğŸ™ˆ Introducing .gitignore
In a Git project, there are several types of files and directories that you typically want to keep out of our repositories to keep things clean, secure, and easy to manage. What you ignore will depend on the type of project and the coding languages youâ€™re using, but all Github projects use a file called .gitignore to let Git know what to ignore.
In general, the following kinds of files shouldnâ€™t be tracked in Github:

Sensitive files: Files containing passwords or private information
Big files: Git isnâ€™t built to keep track of large files.

For R and Quarto projects, this will include the following common files types:

Session and history files: .Rhistory, .RData, .Rproj.user/
Knitting files: .utf8.md, .knit.md
Output/render folders: *_files/ ,_site/, _book/
Editor and IDE Config Files: .Rproj.user/

Donâ€™t worry if you donâ€™t fully understand what all of these files are yet. The important thing here is to know is that there are things we should and should not upload to Git, and the way we keep the things we donâ€™t want in git out is by using a .gitignore file.

4.2.1 Exercise 2: Make a .gitignore
Letâ€™s make a .gitignore now using the command line. Type the following code into the Terminal to make your new file using the touch command:
touch .gitignore
Then open .gitignore in the Files pane in RStudio. If you donâ€™t see the .gitignore in your file pane, you may need to refresh by clicking the refresh icon at the top right of the file pane.
Once you have your blank .gitignore file open, add the following lines:
*.html 
_site/ 
.Rproj.user/
Letâ€™s break down what each of these mean:

*.html : Ignore all .html files (rendered outputs)
_site/: Ignore the entire contents of the _site folder
.Rproj.user/: Ignore the hidden RStudio files

Save the file, then check your Git status again:
git status
Now the .html file should be gone from the list of red files Git â€œseesâ€ because weâ€™ve told it to ignore these types of files. âœ¨
Before moving forward, letâ€™s add a few more things to the .gitignore to cover all our bases.
Copy and paste the following code into your .gitignore file.
# R
.Rhistory
.RData
.Rproj.user/

# Quarto
*.html
*_files/
*.utf8.md
*.knit.md
_site/
_book/

# System
.DS_Store
Save and close the file.

title: 4Â  Creating your first commit
section: 4.3 âœ… Add the Files You Do Want (Staging)
text:
4.3 âœ… Add the Files You Do Want (Staging)
Now that weâ€™ve told Git what we donâ€™t want to keep track of, we need to tell Git to track the rest of our files. Weâ€™ll do that by using the add command
Type the run the following command in your terminal:
git add .
The . after the add means â€œadd everything in this folderâ€ (ignoring anything listed in .gitignore.)
Run git status again
The output should look something like this now:
On branch main

No commits yet

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage)
        new file:   .gitignore
        new file:   _quarto.yml
        new file:   my-git-quarto-project.Rproj
        new file:   my-git-quarto-project.qmd
Notice that the heading has changed to â€œChanges to be committedâ€ and files are now shown in green. This is called Staging.

title: 4Â  Creating your first commit
text:
4.4 ğŸ“¸ Take your first Snapshot (Commit)
Now that youâ€™ve told Git which files you care about, itâ€™s time to take a â€œsnapshotâ€ of these files.
Run the following in your command line:
git commit -m "Initial commit: set up Quarto project"
âœ… Youâ€™ve saved the first version of your project locally (AKA on your computer)! Next, weâ€™ll learn how to send this â€œsnapshotâ€ of our project to Github for safe keeping.

title: 5Â  Pushing to Github
text:
5.1 Step 1: Create a Repository on GitHub
Now that your project has been committed locally, letâ€™s put it on GitHub so you can back it up and collaborate with others.
Youâ€™ll now see a page with instructions on how to connect your local folder to this GitHub repository.

title: 5Â  Pushing to Github
text:
Go to github.com and log in.
Click the + in the upper right corner â†’ choose â€œNew repositoryâ€.
Complete the form by doing the following:

Fill in the Repository name field, using the same name as your project folder (e.g.Â my-quarto-project)
Leave Description blank or optional
Leave the box unchecked that says â€œInitialize this repository with a READMEâ€ (Weâ€™ll add this on our own later)
Click Create repository

title: 5Â  Pushing to Github
section: 5.2 Step 2: Connect Your Local Git Project to GitHub
text:
5.2 Step 2: Connect Your Local Git Project to GitHub
In the Quick setup â€” if youâ€™ve done this kind of thing before box, click the copy button next to the SSH URL box.
Navigate to the Terminal tab inside your RStudio Quarto project, type the following command but replace the repo name with the one you just copied from Github:
git remote add origin git@github.com:your-name/your-repo-name.git
Now run the command by hitting enter.
Now weâ€™ll set our main branch name to main by running:
git branch -M main
Lastly, weâ€™ll push our main branch to Github by running:
git push -u origin main

title: 5Â  Pushing to Github
section: 5.3 Recap: What Do These Commands Do?
text:
5.3 Recap: What Do These Commands Do?
Ok, we just did a lot there. Letâ€™s pause for a moment and breakdown everything we just did:

git remote add origin ...: Tells Git where your online repository lives (on GitHub).
git branch -M main: Renames your current branch to main (standard practice on GitHub).
git push -u origin main: Uploads your local commits to GitHub and sets up a link between your local main branch and the main branch on GitHub.


ğŸ‰ Congratulations: Now your project is on GitHub!

title: 5Â  Pushing to Github
section: 5.4 ğŸ¯ Exercise 3: Explore Your GitHub Project
text:
5.4 ğŸ¯ Exercise 3: Explore Your GitHub Project
Go to your repository page on GitHub. You should see all your project files, including .qmd, .gitignore, etc.
âœ… Your project is now tracked by Git and backed up on GitHub.
Pay attention to whatâ€™s showing in the file list. Youâ€™ll see some helpful information about the project.
Including:

Which user made the most recent commit
The commit message
The commit number
The timestamp of the commit In the file list
The commit message and timestamp from the most recent update made to each file or folder.







Note



Not every file will update with each git push. Git only keeps track of changes to files. If you made no edits to a file in a commit, it wonâ€™t change. Timestamps will help you track when updates were last made different parts of your project!

title: 5Â  Pushing to Github
text:
5.5 Checkin point.
At this point in the guide, youâ€™ve learned how to:

Create a new RStudio project
Turn on Git tracking with git init
Stage and commit changes
Connect the project to GitHub
Push your first commit

Next up: weâ€™ll learn how to make changes, track versions, and collaborate like pros.

title: 6Â  Making and pushing changes
text:
6.1 ğŸ¯ Goal
By the end of this chapter, youâ€™ll know how to:
Youâ€™ll also practice writing good commit messages and checking your work.

title: 6Â  Making and pushing changes
text:
Make a meaningful change to your project
Stage and commit that change using Git
Push the change to GitHub to save your work.

title: 6Â  Making and pushing changes
section: 6.2 ğŸ› ï¸ Step 1: Make a Small Change
text:
6.2 ğŸ› ï¸ Step 1: Make a Small Change
Letâ€™s open your Quarto file you made in Chapter 1 (e.g., 01-index.qmd) and make a couple changes.
Replace the auto-generated text and code blocks in the file with the following
---
title: "Intro to Git"
format: html
---

# Summary

Here is a summary of the `mtcars` dataset.
Under the summary header and description, add a code chunk with the following:
summary(mtcars)
Save the file. Now check the status in your Terminal again by running:
git status
Youâ€™ll see something like as a Terminal response:
On branch main
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/main'.

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
        modified:   01-index.qmd
Letâ€™s break this down :
The red text tells us that Git sees something was modified in your 01-index.qmd. Itâ€™s under the Changes not staged for commit: section, which tells us that Git hasnâ€™t staged it yet (so it wonâ€™t be saved in the next commit).

title: 6Â  Making and pushing changes
text:
6.3 ğŸ“¥ Step 3: Stage the Change
We want to tell Git, â€œHey, save this file in the next snapshot.â€
Weâ€™ll do this by adding the modified file to the snapshot. We can do that by running:
git add 01-index.qmd
Now, check the status again.
git status
Now youâ€™ll see your file in green and following message:
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
  modified:   01-index.qmd`
ğŸ‰ Great! The change is now staged.

title: 6Â  Making and pushing changes
text:
6.4 Step 4: Commit the Change
Now, weâ€™ll save the snapshot (in Gitâ€™s memory). When we do so, weâ€™ll want to include a descriptive commit message noting what we changed.
Type something like the following and git enter
git commit -m "Add summary of mtcars dataset"
A few best practices for commit messages:
âœ… Use present tense: "Add summary of...", not "Added..."
âœ… Keep it short but descriptive
âœ… Think: â€œWhat changed in this version?â€
ğŸ•µï¸â€â™€ï¸ Good commit messages make it easier for you and others to pick up where you left off. If something breaks during an update or you need to go back to a prior version, commit messages will help your retrace your steps.

title: 6Â  Making and pushing changes
section: 6.5 â˜ï¸ Step 5: Push It to GitHub
text:
6.5 â˜ï¸ Step 5: Push It to GitHub
Now, weâ€™ll send the snapshot from your computer to GitHub by running:
git push
Now go to your repository on GitHub.com â€” youâ€™ll see your commit listed under the Commits tab and your file under Code!






Note



You may be wondering why our push command is shorter than it was last time. In our last push, we needed to connect our remote main branch to the remote Github repository. Since weâ€™re already connected our Quarto project to Github and set our branch to main, we can just use the git push command now.



ğŸ’¡ GitHub is now your projectâ€™s cloud backup and collaboration hub.

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
1.1 What is the Terminal, Anyway?
First things first:
If youâ€™ve never opened a Terminal window before, youâ€™re not alone. This guide is here to show you that the command line isnâ€™t something to fear. Itâ€™s just a different way to tell your computer what to do â€” directly, and often much faster.
You donâ€™t need to memorize anything right now. You donâ€™t need to be a â€œtech wizard.â€ You just need a little curiosity.
A few important things before you get started:
Time to enter the Matrix, Neo.
Think of using the Terminal like dmâ€™ing your computer.
Instead of clicking buttons or opening folders with a mouse or trackpad, you type commands in the command line asking your computer to do these things for you. Your computer reads your message and replies by immediately doing what you ask.
The Terminal (on Mac) or Git Bash (on Windows) are programs that can run a shell, are just the names of the user interfaces where you will type these commands.
The Terminal might look a little old-school (and letâ€™s be real: a bit scary ğŸ‘»), but itâ€™s still one of the most powerful tools you can learn. People who work in code, data, security, and tech use it all the time.
Hereâ€™s just a few examples of what we can ask our computers to do using the Terminal:
We can do all of these things by typing just a few words. But to communicate effectively with our Terminals, we have to learn â€œspeakâ€ its language. In this guide, youâ€™ll learn the basics of this language to get you started.

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
Terminology note



People (including the authors of this guide) will use the term shell and terminal and command line interchangeably. This means when we say â€œtype into your shellâ€, â€œin your command lineâ€, or â€œin your terminalâ€, we mean type at the prompt in your Terminal or Git Bash program. Later, weâ€™ll use our Terminal from within Visual Studio Code.
In reality, there are some nuances:

The terminal opens a window.
Inside that, a shell runs.
You interact with it through the command line interface.

In practical terms, just know they usually mean the same thing out in the wild.





List all the files in a folder
Create a new folder
Install programs
Move files around
Automate tasks

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
1.3 How to Open the Terminal
First things first, we need to actually open the Terminal on our machines.
Hereâ€™s how to find it on your computer:

Mac:
Press Command + Space, type Terminal, and hit Enter.
Windows:
Open the Start Menu, search for Terminal or PowerShell, and open it.
(Thereâ€™s also something called â€œCommand Promptâ€ â€” close enough for now.)
Linux:
Press Ctrl + Alt + T â€” itâ€™s probably already installed!

Tip: If you want, you can change the Terminalâ€™s color theme to make it more comfortable to look at. (Weâ€™ll cover this later.)

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
section: 1.4 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
text:
1.4 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
Ok, now that the Terminal is open on your computer, letâ€™s take a quick look at the text showing in the window when you launch to familiarize ourselves with basics of the interface.






Note for newer Mac users



When you launch the Terminal for the first time, youâ€™ll probably see a prompt saying something like:
The default interactive shell is now zsh.
To update your account to use zsh, please run `chsh -s /bin/zsh`.
DISREGARD THIS MESSAGE. Do not run this the command to update to zsh. Zsh is a similar language that Mac is transitioning to by default. However, we will use Bash for this guide to keep everyone on the same page, regardless of their operating systems.





When you launch Terminal for the first time, youâ€™ll see some text like this.


Letâ€™s breakdown a few things from the screenshot above:

Computer name: the characters before the ~ are your computer name.
Current directory: The ~ character is Terminal shorthand for your â€œbaseâ€ directory on your computer. The value shown here will update as you move around to different folders on your computer.
User name: The part immediatetely after the ~ is your username.
Command prompt: Lastly we have the $. This is the â€œpromptâ€ where you type commands.

You type your commands AFTER the $ and then hit Return/Enter on your keyboard to run or execute them. Weâ€™ll practice doing just that in the next section.

1.4.1 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
Letâ€™s try your first real command: finding out where you are using the command pwd.
In the Terminal prompt (remember after the $), type the following command:
pwd
Then press Enter to run the command.
You should see Terminal respond with something like this:
/Users/yourname
or this
C:\Users\yourname
Depending on your system, the path may look a little different â€” and thatâ€™s OK.
So what just happened?

pwd stands for â€œprint working directory.â€
It simply asks: Where am I right now in the computerâ€™s folder system?
Your computer provides the answer: your current folder â€” usually your â€œhomeâ€ directory when you first open the Terminal.

title: 1Â  Welcome to the Terminal
section: 1.5 Quick Tips Before You Move On
text:
1.5 Quick Tips Before You Move On

Command Case Matters in the Terminal: pwd is not the same as PWD.
Press Enter: Every command you type needs an Enter to run.
You Canâ€™t Break It Easily: Typing pwd wonâ€™t hurt your computer.
(In fact, almost everything weâ€™ll do today is safe.)

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
1.2 Speaking the Terminalâ€™s language
The programming language we will use for our interactions in the Terminal is called Bash. Bash is a Unix-based program and most of the Internet runs on Unix (or Linux) computers.
Macs understand Bash natively, but Windows doesnâ€™t understand Bash at all without the help of another program. This is why Git and Git Bash were downloaded in the prerequisites â€“ so we can all speak the same language, regardless of the machines weâ€™re using.

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.1 Whatâ€™s in This Folder? (ls)
Now that you know where you are (pwd), itâ€™s time to explore whatâ€™s around you. Specifically, weâ€™ll start by moving between different folders on your computer.
If you want to see whatâ€™s inside the current directory, you use the ls command.
As we said in Chapter 1, the Terminal lets you interact with files the same way you would with File Explorer on Windows and Finder on a Mac â€” except youâ€™ll be using text instead of clicking.
When your first launch terminal, youâ€™ll see a ~ (called a tilde), which lets you know youâ€™re in your base or home directory. We want to ask the Terminal to tell us what is inside this home directory.
To do that, type the following command:
and press Enter to run the command.
Terminal will respond to your command with a list of files and folders like this:
Or it might be different depending on whatâ€™s in your computerâ€™s home folder.
In any case, the list of directories returned by Terminal will match the folders you would see if you clicked on your home directory in the Finder on a Mac or in File Explorer on a Windows machine. For example, the list of folders listed in the example response above matches what we see in our home directory using Finder below.
Quick Recap: What does ls stand for?
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
ls


_projects Desktop       Downloads   Movies      Pictures
Documents   Library     Music       Public 




Itâ€™s short for â€œlist.â€
It literally says, â€œList whatâ€™s here.â€
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.2 Step 2: Moving Around (cd)
Seeing whatâ€™s around is nice â€” but what if you want to go into one of those folders?
Use the cd command, shorthand for â€œchange directoryâ€.
Suppose you see a folder called Documents.
To do so, type the following command in your Terminal:
cd Documents
and press Enter.
Now youâ€™re inside the Documents directory!
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
section: 2.3 How Can You Tell Where You Are Now?
text:
2.3 How Can You Tell Where You Are Now?
There are a couple ways to make sure you are where you think you are in the Terminal.
The first is to look at the command prompt line inside your Terminal window again. You should see something like:
Anas-MacBook-Air:Documents ana$
In the current directory space (where there used to be a ~), you should now see the name of the Documents folder. Remember if youâ€™re ever unsure where you are, Terminal will tell you in the prompt!
If youâ€™re still not sure, remember you can use your new friend the pwd command from Chapter 1 by typing:
pwd
Terminal should now show something like:
/Users/yourname/Documents
or
C:\Users\yourname\Documents
Nice job â€” you just moved between directories!
Now letâ€™s try sending the ls command again by typing:
ls
and hitting Enter.
You should see a different list of files and/or folder names that you did when you ran the same command inside the home directory â€” now showing the contents of your Documents folder.
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.4 Step 3: Going Back Up
Ok now that weâ€™ve moved into folders, what if you want to go back to the folder you came from?
To go back up, type and run the following command:
cd ..
The two dots .. simply mean â€œthe folder above this one.â€
If you run the pwd command again, youâ€™ll see youâ€™re back to where you started!
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.5 Extra: Special Shortcuts
Here are a few handy shortcuts youâ€™ll want to remember:



Command
What it does




cd
Go back to your home directory.


cd ..
Move up one directory.


cd foldername
Move into a folder.




Tip: If the folder name has spaces (like My Documents), put it in quotes:
cd "My Documents"

Or use a backslash to â€œescapeâ€ the space:
cd My\ Documents
Like we mentioned before, Terminal is particular about the way you speak to it. For it to understand you, youâ€™ve got to speak its language. But this is another reason why naming your files and directories cleanly using a naming convention like snake_case or kebab-case will help you work more efficiently.
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
section: 2.3 How Can You Tell Where You Are Now? (pwd)
text:
2.3 How Can You Tell Where You Are Now? (pwd)
There are a couple ways to make sure you are where you think you are in the Terminal.
The first is to look at the command prompt line inside your Terminal window again. You should see something like:
Anas-MacBook-Air:Documents ana$
In the current directory space (where there used to be a ~), you should now see the name of the Documents folder. Remember if youâ€™re ever unsure where you are, Terminal will tell you in the prompt!
If youâ€™re still not sure, remember you can use your new friend the pwd command from Chapter 1 by typing:
pwd
Terminal should now show something like:
/Users/yourname/Documents
or
C:\Users\yourname\Documents
Nice job â€” you just moved between directories!
Now letâ€™s try sending the ls command again by typing:
ls
and hitting Enter.
You should see a different list of files and/or folder names that you did when you ran the same command inside the home directory â€” now showing the contents of your Documents folder.
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.4 Step 3: Going Back Up (cd ..)
Ok now that weâ€™ve moved into folders, what if you want to go back to the folder you came from?
To go back up, type and run the following command:
cd ..
The two dots .. simply mean â€œthe folder above this one.â€
If you run the pwd command again, youâ€™ll see youâ€™re back to where you started!
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.6 ğŸ“ Mini Exercise
Own your own, try this:

Open your Terminal.
Type pwd to see where you are.
Use ls to list whatâ€™s inside.
Pick a folder you see (not your Documents folder).
cd into that folder.
Use pwd again to check that you moved.
cd .. to come back up.

Take your time. Play around.
If you get lost, just type:
cd
to jump back to your home directory.
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
ls


_projects Desktop       Downloads   Movies      Pictures
Documents   Library     Music       Public 




Itâ€™s short for â€œlist.â€
It literally says, â€œList whatâ€™s here.â€
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.2 Moving Around (cd)
Seeing whatâ€™s around is nice â€” but what if you want to go into one of those folders?
Use the cd command, shorthand for â€œchange directoryâ€.
Suppose you see a folder called Documents.
To do so, type the following command in your Terminal:
cd Documents
and press Enter.
Now youâ€™re inside the Documents directory!
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.4 Going Back Up (cd ..)
Ok now that weâ€™ve moved into folders, what if you want to go back to the folder you came from?
To go back up, type and run the following command:
cd ..
The two dots .. simply mean â€œthe folder above this one.â€
If you run the pwd command again, youâ€™ll see youâ€™re back to where you started!
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.1 Creating a Folder (mkdir)
Now that you can move around the Terminal like a pro, itâ€™s time to create your own stuff.
In this chapter, weâ€™ll learn to make new folders and files. Weâ€™ll also learn how to move or delete them.
Letâ€™s say you wanted to make a brand new folder on your computer. If you were doing this in Finder, youâ€™d do something like right click and hit New Folder, then youâ€™d need to fill out your folder name in the prompt next to the new folder.
To do this from the command line, we do all of this in a single prompt using the mkdir command.
If you ran the following command (donâ€™t do this):
This would create a folder called my_new_folder inside whatever directory youâ€™re inside in the Terminal.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
mkdir stands for make directory.


mkdir my_new_folder


3.1.1 ğŸ“ Mini excercise: make a directory
Now, try the mkdir command out on your own by making a new directory inside your home directory (~).

Check youâ€™re in your home directory (Hint: you can get back to your home directory by running cd)
Type and run: mkdir terminal_practice in your command prompt
Run the ls command to make sure it worked, You should see your new directory listed in the Terminal response.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.2 Creating a File (touch)
Like folders, we can also make new files from the command line using the touch command.

Unlike other commands weâ€™ve learned, touch isnâ€™t shorthand for anything. Itâ€™s just the name of the command to make a new, empty file in Bash ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

For example, if you ran the following command:
touch example.txt
This creates a new, empty file called example.txt.

Note: Windows users may need to use:


bash echo.> emample.txt
or bash New-Item example.txt
(Depending on if youâ€™re using PowerShell.)


3.2.1 ğŸ“ Mini excercise: make a file
Now, try the touch command on your own by making a new file inside your new terminal_practice folder.

Move into your new folder: run the command cd terminal_practice to move into your new folder.
Make a new file: Type and run the command touch terminal-file.txt.
Check your work: Run the ls command to list the files in your folder. You should see a single file listed in the Terminal response called terminal-file.txt.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
section: 4.1 Youâ€™ll get used to them quickly!
text: 4.1 Youâ€™ll get used to them quickly!

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
section: 3.2 Hint: you can get back to your home directory by running cd
text: 3.2 Hint: you can get back to your home directory by running cd

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.3 Copying Files and Folders (cp)
We can also make duplicate files or folders from command line using the cp command.

cp is shorthand for â€œcopyâ€

Syntax of the cp command
cp source_file_folder destination_file_folder
The cp command takes at least two arguments in its arguments:

Source file or folder: the file or folder you want to copy
Destination file or folder: the name youâ€™d like the copy of the file or folder to be called

Try running the following inside your terminal_practice folder:
cp notes.txt copy_of_notes.txt
If you run ls again, you should now you have two files: the original (notes.txt) and the new copy (copy_of_notes.txt).
As we said before, the cp command can also copy whole directories. However, itâ€™s a little more nuanced. If youâ€™d like to learn more about copying folders, please see appendix XXX.
ğŸ“ A note about destination folders: Bash will check to see if the folder you gave it already exists. If it doesnâ€™t, Bash will create the new folder for you and place the file inside of it.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.4 Moving or Renaming Files (mv)**
Moving files or folders from command line is also easy using the mv command. The command can also by used to rename files, depending on the syntax you use.

mv is shorthand for â€œmoveâ€

Syntax of the mv command
To move a fileâ€™s location, use the following syntax:
mv source_file destination_folder
If you just want to rename a file, use the following syntax:
mv oldname.txt newname.txt
Weâ€™ll practice the two ways to use the mv command in the next exercise.

3.4.1 ğŸ“ Mini exercise: move and rename a file

3.4.1.1 Part 1: move the file

Make new subdirectory: run the command mkdir my_new_folder to make a new folder in your terminal_practice directory.
Peek at our files: run ls to look at the files inside your terminal_practice folder to make sure the new folder is there.
Move your notes.txt file: Move the copy of your notes files into the new sub-folder in your directory by running the following command: mv copy_of_notes.txt my_new_folder/
Check that it worked: run ls to look at the files inside your terminal_practice folder. You should still see a new folder called `my_new_folder but you should not see the copy of your notes file.
Locate your notes copy file: run cd my_new_folder to move into your new folder. Then run ls to peek at the files. You should see your copy of the notes file listed.



3.4.1.2 Part 2: rename the file

Rename your notes copy file: From inside your new folder, rename the copy of your notes file by running the following command: mv copy_of_notes.txt notes_new.txt
Check that it worked: run ls to look at your files. You should see the copy of your notes files, but now with a new name

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.5 Deleting Files and Folders (rm)
You can also use the command line to delete files and folders on your machine using the rm command.

rm is shorthand for â€œremoveâ€

This command does require some caution because when you delete something from the Terminal, it doesnâ€™t go to the Trash â€” itâ€™s gone.
Syntax of the rm command:
Deleting single files:
rm name_file_to_delete
Deleting a folder (and everything inside it):
rm -r folder_to_delete
ğŸ“ Note: The -r here is called a flag. It stands for â€œrecursiveâ€ â€” it tells rm to delete not just the folder, but also anything inside it. Weâ€™ll talk a little more about flags in the next section.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.7 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
Phew. In this chapter youâ€™ve learned a lot:

How to create a new folder/directory (mkdir)
How to create a new file (touch file_name)
How to copy files (cp ..)
How to move and rename files (mv..)
How flags can be used to power-up commands

Next up:
Weâ€™ll learn some key tips and tricks to make your command line workflow more efficient.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.6 Quick Note About Flags ğŸ³ï¸
Flags are extra options you can add to commands to change how they behave.

Theyâ€™re usually a dash plus one or two letters. (Example: -r means â€œrecursiveâ€ for rm)
You can combine flags too (like -rf for rm -r -f, meaning â€œrecursiveâ€ and â€œforce deleteâ€).

Youâ€™ll see flags often out in the wild. As you use the command line more, youâ€™ll start to use more of these flags in your workflow to give you more control over what your commands do. For now, just know when you see something starting with a dash, itâ€™s probably a flag to add a little extra to the primary command.
Optional exercise:
If you want, try one out yourself now by using the -l flag along with the ls command.The flag tells the command line, â€œgive me more information about each file in my directoryâ€.
Run the following command:
ls -l 
Terminal will respond with detailed information about each file and folder in your directory. See the screenshot below for more information about each detail field.



Breakdown of each file detail in the -l flag Terminal response

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
section: 2.7 ğŸ”¥ Pro Tip: Speed Up with Tab Completion
text:
2.7 ğŸ”¥ Pro Tip: Speed Up with Tab Completion
Ok, now that youâ€™ve got some practice typing things into Terminal, weâ€™ll let you in on a big time-saver: when you start typing a folder name, you donâ€™t have to type the whole thing.
Hit the Tab key after typing part of your folder name and the Terminal will try to auto-complete it for you.
See it for yourself by typing:
cd Doc
then press Tab.

If thereâ€™s a Documents folder, Terminal will fill in the rest automatically!

Huge time saver.
Remember, youâ€™ll still need to hit Enter to run the command and move into the Documents folder though.
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.8 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
In this chapter youâ€™ve learned:

How to see whatâ€™s inside a folder (ls)
How to move into a folder (cd foldername)
How to move back up (cd ..)
How to use Tab to speed things up

At this point youâ€™ve started to learn some of the basics of â€œspeakingâ€ Bash.
Next up:
Weâ€™ll learn how to create your own files and folders in the Terminal.
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
4.1 Command History
In this brief chapter, weâ€™ll touch on a few things that should help you work quicker in the Terminal. Weâ€™ll also touch on navigating common issues youâ€™ll probably run into.
The command line keeps a history of the commands you give it. Much like scrolling back up through the messages in a conversation on your phone, you can â€œscroll upâ€ through the conversation youâ€™ve had with the Terminal (only withe Terminal, youâ€™ll only see the messages you sent).
How to view your command history:
To see prior commands youâ€™ve written, just press the up arrow â†‘ on your keyboard. Each press will take you to the prior command in your history.
To get back to an empty prompt, scroll back down using the down arrow â†“
You can re-run any command that pops up simply by hitting the Enter / return key on your keyboard. No need to re-type things!
Why this is useful
In programming, we often repeat commands quite frequently (think about how often you re-run your notebook code in R-Studio, for example).
Having a command history is helpful because it:
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
4.2 Canceling a Command
One of the scariest things for new Terminal users happens when you run something you didnâ€™t mean to.
If you realize you made a mistake while a command is running, press:
Ctrl + C
This cancels the running command and brings you back to the prompt.
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
section: 4.3 Tab Completion (Again, Because Itâ€™s That Good)
text:
4.3 Tab Completion (Again, Because Itâ€™s That Good)
Remember: start typing a folder or file name, press Tab, and Terminal finishes it for you if possible.
Saves time and typos!
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
4.4 Installing Software
Later on, youâ€™ll learn about package managers that make installing programs super easy from the Terminal.
For now, just know these examples:

Mac: brew install something
Linux: apt install something
Windows: choco install something

(Weâ€™ll leave installations for a future guide, so you donâ€™t get overwhelmed.)
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 5Â  Troubleshooting
text:
5.1 Common pitfalls and errors
In this final chapter, letâ€™s touch quickly on navigating common issues you might run into using the Terminal.
Hereâ€™s a quick rundown of the most common problems and errors youâ€™ll run into using the command line. Even experienced developers run into these issues, so learning what they mean will go a long way when troubleshooting.
For more common issues and how to fix them, see the common errors table in the Glossary at the end of this guide.

title: 5Â  Troubleshooting
section: 5.2 How to Get Out of VIM
text:
5.2 How to Get Out of VIM
Every new command line user shares one panic-inducing experience at one point or another: accidentally opening VIM and not knowing how to get out of it.
In this section, weâ€™ll briefly walk you through what VIM is and how to exit it so you donâ€™t panic when this (inevitably) happens to you.
What is VIM?
VIM is a text editor built into most Unix systems, including macOS and Linux. Itâ€™s used by developers to edit code and configuration files, but it works very differently from regular text editors.
If you accidentally open something in vim (for example, by running git commit without a message), it might look like youâ€™re stuck. But donâ€™t worry â€” hereâ€™s how to exit safely.
How to Exit VIM
If you donâ€™t want to save any changes - most common:

Press Esc (to make sure youâ€™re not in input mode)
Type :q! (to â€œquit and ignore changesâ€)
Hit Enter / return (to exit)

If You do want to save changes - less common:

Press Esc
Type :wq (to â€œwrite and quitâ€).
Press Enter / return

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
Saves time â€“ You can quickly repeat or modify previous commands with the â†‘ key instead of retyping them.
Reduces mistakes â€“ Reusing known-good commands lowers the chance of typos or syntax errors.
Aids learning â€“ You can review what youâ€™ve done, which helps you remember your steps and can help with troubleshooting if something goes wrong.
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
4.3 Tab Completion
You read about this in Chapter 2, but itâ€™s worth mentioning again because itâ€™s that good.
Remember: start typing a folder or file name, press Tab, and Terminal finishes it for you if possible.
Saves time and typos!
If thereâ€™s more than one similarly-named files in your folder, you may have to type more characters to get to the one you want.
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 5Â  Troubleshooting
text:
Command not found? You might have a typo or the program isnâ€™t installed.
No such file or directory? Youâ€™re trying to access a file/path that doesnâ€™t exist. Check that the file exists and that your spelled it correctly.
Permission denied?
You tried to do something you donâ€™t have permission to do. Check your file/repo permissions.
Syntax error
You typed a command in a way the shell doesnâ€™t understand. Check that your syntax is correct and error-free.
Stuck in a weird app inside Terminal?
Try pressing Ctrl + C or Ctrl + D to exit.

title: 6Â  Glossary: quick reference
text: 6.1 Terminology

title: 6Â  Cheat sheets
text:
âŒ Error
ğŸ“– What It Means
ğŸ’¡ Fix




command not found
You typed a command the shell doesnâ€™t recognize
Check for typos or whether the tool is installed


No such file or directory
Youâ€™re trying to access a file/path that doesnâ€™t exist
Use ls to explore and make sure the path is correct


Permission denied
You tried to do something you donâ€™t have permission for
Use sudo (if appropriate), or check file permissions


Is a directory
You tried to treat a directory like a file
Double-check what kind of thing youâ€™re trying to use


Not a directory
You tried to treat a file like a folder
Use ls -l to see whatâ€™s a file vs folder


Syntax error
You typed a command in a way the shell canâ€™t parse
Review the correct syntax, especially quotes or flags


Killed or Terminated
The OS stopped a program (often for high memory/CPU usage)
Try a smaller task or check system limits


Getting stuck in VIM
You opened something in vim and canâ€™t exit
Press Esc, then :q!, then Enter to quit

title: 5Â  Troubleshooting
text:
5.3 ğŸ‰ Final Words
Congratulations! Youâ€™ve made it to the end of the Intro to Terminal guide.
Youâ€™ve now learned:

How to open the Terminal
How to move around
How to create and manage files and folders
How to read and use simple flags
How to fix common mistakes

Youâ€™ve built a real foundation for anything else youâ€™ll learn later â€” whether thatâ€™s coding, scripting, data science, or just being more powerful with your own computer.
Remember: the Terminal is your friend.
Keep practicing â€” the more you use it, the more natural it will feel.
Good job! ğŸš€

title: 6Â  Glossary: quick reference
text:
Term
Meaning




Terminal
Text-based way to control your computer


Directory (Folder)
A container for files


Path
The location of a file or folder


Flag
Extra option for a command


pwd
Show current directory (path)


ls
List files and folders


ls -l
List with detailed info


cd foldername
Change into a folder


cd ..
Move up one folder


mkdir name
Make a new folder


touch name.txt
Create a blank file


cp old new
Copy a file


mv old new
Move or rename a file


rm file
Delete a file


rm -r folder
Delete a folder and its contents


Ctrl + C
Cancel a running command


Tab
Autocomplete file/folder names

title: 6Â  Glossary: quick reference
text:
ğŸ““ Term
ğŸ“– What It Means




Command line
The interface where you type and run text commands


Shell
The program that interprets your commands and runs them (e.g.Â bash, zsh)


Terminal
The user interface that displays the shell and lets you interact with it. Examples: Terminal (Mac), Git Bash (Windows)


Directory (Folder)
A container for files


Path
The location of a file or folder


Flag
Extra option for a command
